topics.body:
"@EHAN":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/556f70c46368727b32821900#post_556f70c46368727b32821900
[bq="EHAN"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/556f708e6368727b322e1900#post_556f708e6368727b322e1900
"How can reality be real if our measurements aren't real"[/bq]
Brace yourself; this is without a doubt going to turn into another argument because I've had a couple arguments about this and he thought the Heisenberg uncertainty principle was full of shit.

Reason why there's another inevitable argument about to happen:
Thanotos, "the Heisenberg uncertainty principle is wrong!"
Uc9, "no; *YOU* are wrong!"
Science, "the Heisenberg uncertainty principle is proven true"

It's like the equivalent of whenever me and squiggy argue about shonen; except the difference is that quantum physics isn't subjective opinion but a actual hard non-objective science.

I don't understand? (Maybe because I'm a little tired right now)[/bq]
Are you familiar with "Schrodinger's cat?":https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IOYyCHGWJq4
It's 100% proven.

Basically if you stuff a cat into a box with a grenade or something that has a 1 out of 2 chance of exploding until measured the cat is either alive or dead until measured and that looking in the box forces nature to decide.

topics.body:
"@Number1pegasus":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/556f7cd663687219baaa1100#post_556f7cd663687219baaa1100
Although not what I had in mind theoretically.

Say for example you lean against a wall for a infinite number of years; the chances of you falling through that wall isn't 0% chance, rather it's 1/âˆž chance.  If you were leaning against the wall for a infinite number of years then it's within the realm of possibility that you one time could literally fall through the wall; it could be 10 seconds from now, it could be 100 billion years from now, but if you were to lean against the wall for infinity years eventually it would happen one time.
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/556f7b756368722281b10700#post_556f7b756368722281b10700
[bq="Whatevs"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/556f7a556368727b32632600#post_556f7a556368727b32632600
That and other quantam mechanics (like the Observer effect I think it is called) makes people think we live in a simulation right?[/bq]
It's actually not impossible that we live in a simulation; it's just incredibly unlikely.  2D hologram theory isn't impossible, it's just a fringe science.  If you want to say we live in a simulation it's completely fair to say that it's possible; it's just incredibly unlikely but still possible.  It's like saying that your lottery ticket in the winning ticket; it's incredibly unlikely but still possible.
